net.openhft.lang

Enum MemoryUnit

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<MemoryUnit>
      • net.openhft.lang.MemoryUnit
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable<MemoryUnit>

    public enum MemoryUnit
extends Enum<MemoryUnit>
    A MemoryUnit represents memory amounts at a given unit of granularity and provides utility methods to convert across units. A MemoryUnit does not maintain memory information, but only helps organize and use memory amounts representations that may be maintained separately across various contexts.

    Note than in this class kilo-, mega- and giga- prefixes means 2^10 = 1024 multiplexing, that is more common in low-level programming, CPU and operation system contexts, not 1000 as defined by International System of Units (SI).

    A MemoryUnit is mainly used to inform memory amount-based methods how a given memory amount parameter should be interpreted.

    API of MemoryUnit is copied from TimeUnit enum.

    • Enum Constant Detail

      • BITS

        public static final MemoryUnit BITS
        Memory unit representing one bit.

      • BYTES

        public static final MemoryUnit BYTES
        Memory unit representing one byte, i. e. 8 bits.

      • LONGS

        public static final MemoryUnit LONGS
        Memory unit representing 8 bytes, i. e. 64-bit word, the width of Java's primitive long type.

      • CACHE_LINES

        public static final MemoryUnit CACHE_LINES
        Memory unit representing 64 bytes, i. e. the most common CPU cache line size.

      • KILOBYTES

        public static final MemoryUnit KILOBYTES
        Memory unit representing 1024 bytes.

      • PAGES

        public static final MemoryUnit PAGES
        Memory unit representing 4096 bytes, i. e. the most common native memory page size.

      • MEGABYTES

        public static final MemoryUnit MEGABYTES
        Memory unit representing 1024 kilobytes.

      • GIGABYTES

        public static final MemoryUnit GIGABYTES
        Memory unit representing 1024 megabytes.

      • convert

        public long convert(long sourceAmount,
           MemoryUnit sourceUnit)
        Converts the given memory amount in the given unit to this unit. Conversions from finer to coarser granularities truncate, so lose precision. For example, converting 7 bits to bytes results in 0. Conversions from coarser to finer granularities with arguments that would numerically overflow saturate to Long.MIN_VALUE if negative or Long.MAX_VALUE if positive.

        For example, to convert 4096 bytes to cache lines, use: MemoryUnit.CACHE_LINES.convert(4096L, MemoryUnit.BYTES)

        Parameters:
        sourceAmount - the memory amount in the given sourceUnit
        sourceUnit - the unit of the sourceAmount argument
        Returns:
        the converted amount in this unit, or Long.MIN_VALUE if conversion would negatively overflow, or Long.MAX_VALUE if it would positively overflow.

      • align

        public long align(long amountToAlign,
         MemoryUnit unit)
        Aligns the given memory amount in the given unit to this unit. For example, aligning 1000 bytes to kilobytes results in 1024. Negative values are aligned towards negative infinity: e. g. aligning -5 longs to cache lines results in -8.
        Parameters:
        amountToAlign - the memory amount in the given unit
        unit - the unit of the amountToAlign argument
        Returns:
        the aligned amount, still in the given unit
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given unit is finer than this unit, or if the aligned value overflows long bounds

      • alignAndConvert

        public long alignAndConvert(long sourceAmount,
                   MemoryUnit sourceUnit)
        Equivalent to convert(align(sourceAmount, sourceUnit), sourceUnit).
        Parameters:
        sourceAmount - the memory amount in the given sourceUnit
        sourceUnit - the unit of the sourceAmount argument
        Returns:
        the saturated converted amount in this unit
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given sourceUnit is finer than this unit, or if the aligned value overflows long bounds
